source.4f7d047a:
splited_date = df["last_updated"].str.split(",")
Updated_year = list()

for date in splited_date:
    Updated_year.append(date[1])
    
df["updated_year"] = Updated_year
source.884d9a74:
C = df["rating"].mean()
m = df["rating_count"].quantile(0.9)

def weighted_rating(x, m=m, C=C):
    v = x['rating_count']
    R = x['rating']
    # Calculation based on the IMDB formula
    return (v/(v+m) * R) + (m/(m+v) * C)




df["weighted_rating"] = df.apply(weighted_rating , axis =1)

## Data Engineering 
Before we jump into Graphics we want to create comes features that can help us in understanding some of the features 
- Updated_Year
- Rating percentage (rainting_count/total_user)
- Weight_rating ( I Will be using IMDB's weighted rating (wr) system )
source.d34e0d5b:
# Introduction 
Let's first look ar the datasets to have some idea of what each columns represents. 
We will be using 20 samples as a guild line
- Title is the name of the extension name 
- Url is the url link to the chrome extension. note mose URL does not work any more
- Summary is the descroption and usage of the chrome extension. States the benefits of the extension 
- user_count is the total user download count chrome extensions. Note: the highest count seems to be 10,000,000 
- rating is the overal goold rating of the chrome extension
- rating_count is the total users who rated the chrome extension
- Last_update is the late date of the chrome extension update is in M/D/Y formate. 
- Offer_by is the compnay or organisation who developed or publish the chrome extension. 
- category sates what sector does the chrome extension lies into.
- img_Url is the irl link to the chrome extension incon image . note most url does not work anymore
- descroption is the description of the chrome extension has similar content to "summary"
- language is to spacify the user lanaguage for the chrome extension
- developer_indo is the contact to the chrome extension developer
